steps.title: Remove the old insole from your shoe.
steps.content: Remove the old insole from your shoe. Shake off any dirt or surface grime.

steps.title: Place the old insole over cardboard.
steps.content: Place the old insole over cardboard. The cardboard needs to be thick and preferably have a "cushioned" feel to it - old cartons are good.

steps.title: Trace the insole shape with a pencil.
steps.content: Trace the insole shape with a pencil. Once you have the shape right, you can go over the outline with a marker to make it easier to see.

steps.title: Cut out the insole design.
steps.content: Cut out the insole design. Use scissors that are sharp enough to cut cardboard easily. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat.
steps.content: Repeat. Make two insoles for each shoe. This will allow you to air one insole and insert the other, extending the life of both insoles.

steps.title: Trace a flip flop or shoe that is your size onto the smooth side of a yoga or exercise mat.
steps.content: Trace a flip flop or shoe that is your size onto the smooth side of a yoga or exercise mat. Use a mat that you no longer want; if you can't find one, look in a charity store for throwaway mats. Keep the rest of the mat in your craft cupboard for other uses.

steps.title: Cut out the design that you have traced.
steps.content: Cut out the design that you have traced. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Flip over the cut insole.
steps.content: Flip over the cut insole. Trace it again on the smooth side to create the insole for the opposite foot. Cut out this insole. Now you have both a right and a left foot insole.

steps.title: Trace and cut out four more for both the right and left.
steps.content: Trace and cut out four more for both the right and left. This means that you'll have a total of five cut-outs for each foot.

steps.title: Stack the cut-outs for each foot.
steps.content: Stack the cut-outs for each foot. Place the textured side up.

steps.title: Glue four of the layers together, using a hot glue gun.
steps.content: Glue four of the layers together, using a hot glue gun . Glue a little, then press. Then glue a little more, and press. If you try to glue the whole layer at once, it'll start to dry before you push the layers together.

steps.title: Leave to dry completely.
steps.content: Leave to dry completely. Once dry, you have new insoles!

steps.title: Purchase a roll of self-adhesive cork.
steps.content: Purchase a roll of self-adhesive cork.

steps.title: Roll out a piece of the self-adhesive cork to the length of the shoe.
steps.content: Roll out a piece of the self-adhesive cork to the length of the shoe. Trace around the shoe shape onto the cork (drawing on the paper on the back is likely to be easier). [3] X Research source Do this for both the right and left foot. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Cut out the drawn shape.
steps.content: Cut out the drawn shape. [5] X Research source If you want a thicker insert, cut out two to three layers for each shoe.

steps.title: If you have cut out layers, press these together with care.
steps.content: If you have cut out layers, press these together with care.

steps.title: Line the shoe.
steps.content: Line the shoe. Peel off the backing and carefully slip the insole inside the shoe. Press down to adhere. A little Zippo lighter fuel will make the gluey side slicker for easy insertion, and it dries quickly.
